edu.harvard.data.io

Interface TableReader<T extends DataTable>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    AutoCloseable, Closeable, Iterable<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    CombinedTableReader, FileTableReader, HdfsTableReader, S3TableReader

    public interface TableReader<T extends DataTable>
extends Iterable<T>, Closeable
    Marker interface for class that sequentially reads the records of a data set. A TableReader implements the Iterable interface, allowing it to be used in an enhanced for loop, and the Closeable interface which enables compile-time checking that the Closeable.close() method has been called properly, and to allow the TableReader to be used in a try-with-resources construct.

    A typical pattern to iterate through the records of a TableReader would be: 

     
 try (
   TableReader<IdentityMap> in = getTableReader(context, format,Â IdentityMap.class)
 ) {
   for (final IdentityMap id : in) {
     identities.put((T) id.get(mainIdentifier), id);
   }
 } catch (final IterationException ie) {
   final Throwable e = ie.getCause();
   // Exception handler code.
 }
    Note that the iteration process can throw an instance of IterationException. This occurs when an exception is encountered inside the Iterator.hasNext() or Iterator.next() methods. Since the Iterator interface does not declare any checked exceptions, we instead wrap any exceptions in a runtime exception and rely on the calling code to catch them.

    • Method Summary

      • Methods inherited from interface java.lang.Iterable

        forEach, iterator, spliterator

      • Methods inherited from interface java.io.Closeable

        close
